reviewText: As is often the case these days, movies like CLICK are often promoted in ad spots by using some of their funniest bits.  If one watches the trailer for this movie one would assume that the plot would be rife with the usual predictable, though funny, stuff: stop-action with Adam Sandler making adjustments to achieve the usual mischief.  Unfortunately the best shtick is wasted in the promos.What actually emerges is a very interesting and serious movie about a man who, wanting to adjust his reality, discovers that things as they are aren't really that bad.  Christopher Walken plays an angel that shows the facts to Sandler's character.  What if things were different? What if you could fast forward through the bad and keep the good?  What if, what if, what if.  Sounds pretty good on the surface.But then something, in my opinion, goes decidedly wrong.  The writers and director decide to pack the film with a bunch of crude and disjointed jokes and themes that keep getting in the way.  Dogs humping legs and stuffed animals and each other may be funny once in a while but when the over-amorous canines go at it again and again and again...well...what the viewer gets is a boring, perverse "fake-fingernail-in-the-hamburger" experience that really gets in the way. And the canine crazies are the very least of the problems here.  There are plenty of tasteless human anatomical and sexual situations to give the dogs a solid run for the money.The story is wonderful and has a great message but it gets bogged down over and over by the unnecessary nonsense thrown in seemingly because we, the viewers, wouldn't want to see Sandler in a serious role.If you can find this one in some edited form, with all the crude and rude stuff appropriately excised do it.  Otherwise be prepared to wade through a lot of stuff that dilutes and diminishes the beauty of the story. Three stars (and that's being very generous) for the good that's there.THE HORSEMAN

reviewText: Like many movie watchers, I have mixed feelings with Adam Sandler as an actor.  Sometimes he's funny, other times he comes across rather obnoxious and annoying.  However for Click he clicks (hehe).  I'm surprised how the pacing of this movie gradually shifts from several over the top comedy segments into a more emotionally devastating sad tone by the conclusion.  The transition is actually amazingly well-executedSo, what's the storyline about?  When Adam Sandler accidentally stumbles upon a mysterious angel of death (Christopher Walken's character) Adam is given a remote device that can alter time in several different ways.  For the most part Adam uses the remote to go into the future and skip over all the family-related annoying aspects of his life that gives him the biggest annoyances (such as his EXTREMELY HOT WIFE (played by Kim Beckinsale) nagging at him to do his chores to name one example).  There's quite a bit of depth to Adam's family which is respectable.  It proves a fair amount of time was devoted to this movie.  I do recall a certain period in 2006 when the hype for Click was pretty high.Later on Adam realizes he can use the remote device to not only skip past the events he doesn't care for but also freeze time, eavesdrop into other peoples conversations and alter the size and shape of his face as well as his boss's body size (played by David Hasselhoff).  Admittedly it gets a bit silly by this point but please, keep watching!!  By the way it's somewhat funny seeing David Hasselhoff play a serious character after a certain hamburger incident he went through a while back.  I haven't seen him play such a role since Knight Rider!Anyway, you're probably wondering how it's possible that with all this skipping into the future chaos and Adam's often overbearing obsession fiddling with his time-travelling remote, how the storyline can possibly become emotional?  It's when Adam realizes that he's skipping ahead TOO much and missing key elements of his family's life.  He realizes he's spending too much time with his work and not enough time with his family.  This is when the storyline changes dramatically.  Like I said above though, it's a natural transition from comedy into seriousness, and trust me, Adam actually comes across convincingly in a serious role.  I know, usually he fails in that regard.By the way there's a Michael Jackson joke that's sort of eerie given the circumstances of his death a few years after this movies release.  Also, the dog humping segments were overkill and unnecessary.  Basically it's a time travelling movie, and one that succeeds in my book.  I know it's really easy to dismiss Adam Sandler as an overrated goofball, but in this one, his performance is actually pretty good so it's highly recommended that you watch it.

reviewText: Watching CLICK is like watching two separate movies. The blatant parallels to IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE are transparent, but that's not what makes Click a clunker. Not that it is a clunker in its entirety, either.The story surrounds Michael Newman (Adam Sandler, WATERBOY), an architect who yearns for peace and harmony in his life. Part of the problem is the competition (keeping up with the Jones') that he has going on with his neighbors. They have a new RV, new toys and new cars, while Michael and his family just get by. One evening he hears the irritating boy next door talking about his father's new universal remote control that's patched into everything (garage door, TV, stereo, etc.) and it's all that Michael can take. So he heads out to the mall and stops at (of all places) Bed, Bath and Beyond. It is the "Beyond" that apparently pulls him in, but once inside all he finds are towels and bedding. He lays down on one of these and then quickly spots a doorway that says "Beyond". It looks rather ethereal yet inviting, so Michael goes on in. What he finds is a whacked out looking guy named Morty (Christopher Walken) who offers him a truly "Universal Remote." This remote control does it all. It can rewind you to your birth so that you can witness it (or your conception, something we should NEVER have to see), or it can fast-forward you through troubling times, like arguments with your spouse or personal illnesses. The dangers of this Universal Remote aren't evident right away. Apparently, as this magical tool gets used to your requests, it does them automatically for you, without you having to push a button. So when Michael fast forwards through arguments with his wife Donna (Kate Beckinsale), the remote does it automatically for him in the future. Thus, large chunks of what might seem like inane discussions suddenly are wiped away.Michael soon discovers that his life is in constant fast forward. His job, his kids, his wife, even his own body, change in rapid succession as the Universal Remote takes over. Trying to give back this dangerous piece of machinery, we soon learn that Morty is much more than he seems.The great thing about the film is the last 2/3 of it (with the exception of the ending, which we'll cover in a moment). When people learn how important life is, it's truly an eye-opener. And this is where Click succeeds. When Sandler's character learns about death and how important it is to live every second of every day, it is heart renderingly pulled off. We get to witness Sandler rewinding time and again the important portions of his life that he missed. And, near the end of his own life, we witness his evolution into a man of distinction, trying to save his son from his own deadly mistakes related to family.Where the film fails is the beginning and it's horribly cliched ending. The beginning of the film is filled with bathroom humor (farting in people's faces) and gag jokes that sag under their own terrible weight. This is where one feels like they are watching an entirely different film when compared to the latter 2/3 of the movie. The characters are one-dimensional and utterly unbelievable (quite the dichotomy from what we see later). This isn't a character evolution issue as much as a script failure.The ending of the film is what finally gives it a poor rating. When we see Sandler lay down at Bed, Bath and Beyond, a creeping disgust enters the mind. The film-makers surely wouldn't use one of the oldest cliches in the book, would they? But, oh yes, they did. Grrr!The unfortunate thing about Click is that it really has a wonderful message and some fine acting moments. Special effect make-up artist Rick Baker also deserves much credit for the aging looks he puts the characters through, from Henry Winkler's role as Sandler's father, to Sean Astin's speedo and chubby swim instructor, it was one of the strongest aspects of the entire production.As a whole, the film fails because of its childish beginnings and over-used style ending. But make no mistake, there are some great moments in here. Just not enough to give it a high ranking.

reviewText: Personally, romantic comedies are critic-proof: you're not supposed to see some big character study epic a la films by Spielberg or Scorsese. He cancels camping trips, forgets events with his kids and unbelievably, can't figure out what remote controls what. So he decides to get a universal remote but thanks to Morty, a quirky salesman(a delightful Christopher Walken), he now has a remote control that actually controls life itself. Dog's too loud? Mute it. Fight with the missus? Skip it. Feel like hitting your boss? Pause it and wail on him. Only, of course, the remote is "special" so it remembers Michael's attitude towards certain events and skips them without warning. Pretty soon he skips entire sections of his life and trying to figure out how to save his life while it's passing by.Now for some good: the casting. Kate Beckinsale is just simply lovely, being a charming wife and still having some spunk and not that "ball and chain" feeling. And of course Chris Walken who acts like he knows it's a terrible movie and decides to just go with it. And Henry Winkler and Julie Kavner are memorable but their roles are just too small. As for Adam Sandler, well...it's kind of like a more tamer version of other comedy roles he's done but he still manages to go for kids swearing and a very horny dog with a thing for a plush duck doll. He kind of works but then he doesn't.The film's tone is probably its biggest problem. Some of the laughs do work such as life based on a DVD menu complete with audio commentary by none other than James Earl Jones. Or when he decides to change his skin color from Hulk green to Barney purple. But other jokes such as farting, the aforementioned kid profanity or "kid getting hit by" jokes don't tend to work. Then the film becomes a complete morality play and we see Michael in the future reacting to missing chunks of his life and it becomes more drama than anything. Not to mention the ending is downright atrocious(save for a good use of a U2 song).The main thing about this movie is this: can you stomach these kinds of movies, especially one who brought you such comedy "masterpieces" as Billy Madison or the Longest Yard? reviewText: "Click" is an enjoyable movie that follows no real pattern of expectations.  I rate a movie by how predictable or unpredictable it is.  And that's "Click"'s strongest point. This woman is one of the best actresses in Hollywood.  Playing the role of a wife whose husband seems to be losing his mind, not to mention his family, cannot be an easy part, yet Beckinsale does it to perfection. reviewText: Among life's few remaining constants is this one: Adam Sandler makes good, entertaining movies.  Some of them might be mindless and juvenile, but they are all fun to watch - and I happen to think that Sandler has evolved into a pretty decent actor.  I must admit, though, that I wasn't all that excited about seeing Click (they must not have had much of Kate Beckinsale in the previews because the woman is some more kind of fine).  It's not exactly a bold, original premise, and the whole point of the story is self-explanatory.  We grow up being told not to wish our lives away, so I guess there was a little bit of a nag factor in the back of my head concerning this modern-day rehashing of the old cliché.  And, yes, some of us have no desire to ever see David Hasselhoff in anything, but fortunately we have such likeable stars as Henry Winkler and Christopher Walken (who's always good) balancing out the Hass factor.It's not a complicated story.  Michael Newman (Sandler) is a workaholic who lets his work come before his family - even his gorgeous wife Donna (Beckinsale).  He thinks he's doing the right thing, pushing himself to get that promotion and move up to that higher salary in order to better take care of his wife and kids.  The wife and kids, of course, start complaining about how they hardly ever get to spend time with him anymore, which leads to arguments, which leads to Michael going a little mental because of all the stress.  Even the lack of a universal remote control is enough to send him storming out of the house.  Sound familiar to anyone?  I think so.  Well, Michael does find a universal remote, courtesy of Morty (Walken) in the Beyond section of the local Bed, Bath, and Beyond.  Forget the TV, this little baby really does give him remote control of his universe.  He can mute the sounds of his angry wife or barking dog, fast forward through such unpleasant tasks as showering or driving to work, freeze frame everyone around him at the click of a button, etc.  Despite Morty's warnings, he comes to rely on the fast forward a little too much, and the next thing you know he's fast forwarding through his entire life, losing years at a time.  He sees the kind of loser he became as he auto piloted his way through life, but by the time he realizes that family should always come first it's too late to do anything about it - or is it?Certainly, there are parallels with It's A Wonderful Life, and you can toss a few pinches of A Christmas Carol in there, as well.  Don't forget the crude humor, since we are talking about an Adam Sandler film here.  You can't have an Adam Sandler film without at least one fart joke (I won't even mention the duck).  Just be glad that David Spade and Jon Lovitz don't pop up anywhere.  Sandler really does have a top-notch cast and crew with him this time (well, except for Hasselhoff).  Beckinsale's charms are obvious, Walken's acting skills are legendary, director Frank Coraci has already proven to be a perfect fit for Sandler in The Wedding Singer and The Waterboy, Rick Baker's make-up effects are top-notch, and the list just goes on.  They even got Dolores O'Riordan to perform a futuristic jazzy version of the Cranberries' Linger (she's the lead singer of the group, in case you didn't know).  It's a little hard for me to see "Fonzie" playing a grandfather, but Henry Winkler still brings an unequalled coolness factor to any project he participates in.  Finally, you also get to see Julie Kavner, the woman behind the voice of Marge Simpson.Adam Sandler fans will almost certainly enjoy this movie, but I think Click should appeal to just about anyone who enjoys a good comedy.  Naturally, some will dismiss the film as stupid, but it isn't completely about the comedy this time around.  There actually is a message to this film, and an important one - it's one you already know, but that doesn't make it any less important.

reviewText: I remember when I was in third grade, I read this children's short story collection called "Uncanny" by Paul Jennings. There was a short story called "Spaghetti Pig Out" which involved this kid getting this magic remote which could control real life, which ends up being used in a spaghetti eating contest. I don't know if there's any connection, but "Click", the new Adam Sandler comedy, also involves a magic remote that can control the things around you.Adam Sandler plays an architect, Michael, a man looking for that next big promotion, so he can give his wife, his son and his daughter all the things he never had as a kid. Working so hard, he just doesn't seem to have enough time to spend with his children, or with his parents or wife. He doesn't even have enough time to memorize which of the remotes in his house operates what. He tries to turn on the TV, but his garage door opens, or the fan goes off. To save some desperately needed time, he goes to a "Beds, Baths and Beyond" store to buy a universal remote, just like the one his neighbours, the O'Doyles, have (I wonder if they're related to the O'Doyles in "Billy Madison"?). Their universal remote, he's told, can be pointed at any appliance and get it to do what he wants to do. He wanders into the "Beyond" section of "Beds, Bath and Beyond", and finds Morty (Christopher Walken), a man who appears to be some sort of scientist. He gives the architect a universal remote all right, a little too universal. It not only controls any appliance, but his own life. Michael can fast forward through things, rewind to reminisce, pause to stop and think, mute anyone too loud or annoying. But the remote doesn't just have video-like commands, but DVD ones too. Michael can access his "life menu", change languages, adjust color, and even get his own commentary (by James Earl Jones, no less). And just like amazon.com, this special remote can remember the users preferences. It all seems pretty great at first, but then of course things start to go wrong, and far beyond anything I expected...It's a great idea, I thought, and I like all the ways in which the remote is used. I also like the fact the film decides to push things forward and go really extreme with some of the remote's consequences toward the end. Christopher Walken was great, he was funny, but also kinda scary in the few parts he had to be. Adam is his usual self, though you get to see him do a bit of dramatic stuff here, a few tears, some emotion, which was interesting to see him do. I reckon he could do a really moving drama comedy one day, if he put his mind to it. He doesn't quite do it here, though.I know I should have expected it, being an Adam Sandler film and everything, but I did find some parta to be a little crude. Sandler seems to be a family man here, and the message of the film is all about family. Having dogs humping giant stuffed ducks and a little girl making comments about crack seemed a little out of place here. Unlike Sandlers other films, where the immature humour kind of fits into the atmosphere, sometimes I felt the writers were being nasty for the sake of nasty. Left a little bit of a bad taste in my mouth.It's a reasonable film, and worth a look because its an interesting concept, though if I had a universal remote like Adam's I'm not sure I'd rewind back to my favorite cinema and watch it again in a hurry. Three and a half stars.
summary: Adam Sandler and His Magic Remote

reviewText: I've gotta hand it to Adam Sandler and his buddies -- the basic idea of "Click!" is great.  Who wouldn't want a truly universal remote that he or she could use to control even a few parts of their world?  I even applaud them for using it as the basis for yet another "man is saved by witnessing himself in an alternate reality" story, ala "It's a Wonderful Life."  After all, if one believes the old saw that nothing truly new has been written since Shakespeare, then this is just another chance to tell such a story with fun, humor, insight, and modern twists.Unfortunately, that's where the problems begin -- the telling.  For a movie with such a fun premise, it's not such a fun -- or funny -- movie.  Oh, it definitely has its comic moments, mostly in schtick played out against the annoying kid next door, but they are too rare and MUCH too obvious.  That is, you see most of the jokes coming at least a couple minutes before they get there.And it's not just the humor that is overly set up, it's the aforementioned premise, as well.  Specifically, if you know the name of the movie and have seen just one of the movie's previews, you get the premise. Unfortunately, Sandler and the other producers apparently didn't think you would understand, so they waste scene after scene early on showing Sandler using and abusing the remote in a mix of circumstances.  So much so that it gets a bit boring, and makes Sandler's character less likeable.As for the other characters, Kate Beckinsale's acting gets better and better as the movie progresses, when she goes from just another good-hearted mom and wife to an older, wiser, and tougher wife who has had to deal with a jerk for most of her married life.  Also -- although I never imagined myself ever writing these words sincerely before -- David Hasselhoff is great.  He's perfect, in fact, in part because it's a role in which you are not asked or expected to like him.  And although I generally love everything Christopher Walken does these days, this is actually one of his weaker roles in a while.  He performs it OK, but the role itself could have been filled just as well by Rip Torn, Christopher Lloyd, or Michael Richards.  That is, the writing fails to take advantage of Walken's unique delivery and presence, leaving him just another wacky old guy.So now that I've picked on the movie for four paragraphs, why did I give it 3 stars?  First, because in general it IS a fun and occasionally funny movie with a heart-warming ending.  Second, because it's all of the above that you can safely let your 8- to 14-year-old children see (although there is a fast forward sex scene that some parents will think is too explicit, as well as relentless dog humping schtick).  But mostly because in the Amazon world, 3 stars is supposed to mean "It's OK," and this film is exactly that.  It's just "OK."

reviewText: Comedy and drama, it's a comedy-drama; and the screenplay is divided in an equal proportion of each. Adam Sandler's character wants a universal remote to make life "easier". What he doesn't expect, however, is that he'll receive a remote that does much more than control the VCR and the TV. It's a universal remote in the truest sense of the word universal; it controls the universe.The first half is hilarious. Sandler has a more mature style of humor in this one. It's not sniffing glue, seeing invisible Penguins, or making silly rhymes. It's slightly less capricious; although, there is still a little bit of fart humor.The second half...well, gets quite serious. As Sandler gets older, the remote starts to become intuitive. He no longer controls the remote; the remote begins to control him. Before he knows it, his life has changed and he has missed much more of his life than he wanted.Other interesting and/or enticing aspects of the movie make it quite enjoyable. Kate Beckinsdale's consistent beauty is worth the ticket alone. In every scene, regardless of attire of makeup, she looks absolutely stunning. The dog that has a sexuality issue causes several huge laughs with nearly the same joke every time. The daughter, when she grows up, is absolutely stunning, and will be a huge star in the very near future. I also enjoyed the appearance of the O'Doyle family, a family that first appeared on the Billy Madison movie. As with Billy Madison, the O'Doyle family experiences a little karmic justice (several times) that really makes the underdog role that Sandler portrays very enjoyable.The guy who is singing in the car will provide huge laughs. David Hasselhoff is strangely brilliant in the prick CEO role. The jogging chick is hypnotic. And Christopher Walken turns in his typically superb performance.The only negative to this movie is the insult of intelligence. For someone with a magic remote, an all-powerful remote, Sandler's character is blindingly ignorant and unimaginative. Anyone with half a brain and any sort of time to think would have been able to come up with much better usages for the remote than Sandler. A concept so vast was somewhat wasted on a static, linear thought process.

reviewText: While I found the movie quite good, I began to think of two things in the movie industry that deeply disturbed me.  The first was Clint Eastwood playing a romantic role in the Bridges of Madison County.  The second is this movie, a serious Adam Sandler movie that has a moral in the plot.When I buy an Adam Sandler movie, I expect a Happy Gilmore, Billy Madison, or an Anger Management type of mindless comedy.  Watching the previews of "Click", I thought that this movie was going to be another piece of mindless comedic genius.I found this movie an excellent piece of work and disturbing at the same time.  "Click" is a movie about an overworked architect named Michael Newman (played by Sandler).  Michael Newman is the perfect example of a middle-aged corporate slave.  He has a beautiful family, but work always seems to get in the way and he never seems to have enough time to play with the kids or spend time with his wife.  In a fit of rage, Newman goes in search of a universal remote control after not being able to figure out what remote controls what.  Newman runs into Morty (Christopher Walken) who gives Newman a Universal Remote (as in a remote that controls the universe).  Newman uses the remote to fast-forward through the seemingly unpleasant portions of life, then finally comes to realize that he missed his whole life.As usual, Christopher Walken is awesome in his portrayal of Morty, a quirky, psychotic techo-geek (plus more).  What I found quite shocking was Sandler's brilliance in the portrayal of Newman, which was actually a serious role.  The comedy in the movie was a definite diversion of the mindless humor I have come to expect of Sandler.  There were some hilarious parts of the movie (the duck and the making of Mike Newman were some of my favorites), but it wasn't the wall-to-wall laughs I was expecting.  Rather, the movie had a very serious theme to it.  As a thirty-something slave to the corporation myself, the movie made me take a step back and review my own life and where I am headed.  As I said before, I felt this was disturbing as I was watching an Adam Sandler film.If you are looking for another Happy Gilmore, this movie isn't it.  I think this is one of those movies that is a compromise between mindless comedy and a chick-flick.  It is a movie to watch with someone you love rather than with a room of drunk friends.Overall, I thought the movie was excellent.  Family Comes First!!

reviewText: Wouldn't it be great if you had a universal remote that you could use to pause, rewind and fast forward your life as you see fit? Skip past all the boring stuff, pause and rewind all the fun stuff. It would be a blast right? Then again, it does kind of sound like the typical "be careful what you wish for?" Hollywood movie.As much as I enjoyed this movie "Click" is highly formulaic and as such, highly predictable. If you don't see every major plot point coming way before it's delivered, then either you weren't paying much attention or you haven't seen that many movies. Don't get me wrong, there is nothing wrong with formulaic and nothing wrong with predictable. Movies succeed or fail far more on execution than originality. Hollywood rarely reinvents the wheel, it just churns out different variations. The only real problem with "Click" is that it gets lost in it's own message and is eventually drowned by the weight of it's dramatic second half.Everything starts out great. The comedy is delivered at a pretty consistent pace without ever diving too far into low-brow areas that Sandler's early movies were known for. There are some great supporting performances from Nick Swardson, Jennifer Coolidge, Henry Winkler and especially David Hasselhoff. This is easily the best performance I ever recall seeing from ol' Dave. He comes so close to going over the top without ever getting there and steals just about every scene he's in. The plot is enjoyable and the characters are funny, but you just know the other foot is going to fall.I admire "Click" for what it tried to accomplish. Sandler is really a better talent then he's ever been given credit for and his performance here is really solid. "Click" won't make you want to change the channel, but it probably won't make you rewind and watch again either.

reviewText: None of Adam Sandler's films are particularly well liked by critics, but audiences always love him. Never the less, "Click" was a new low for the comedy superstar. It got some of the worst reviews of the year and it didn't even manage to "click" with audiences. That didn't stop it from being a box-office success anyway and the film does have its merits. Sandler plays Michael Newman, an architect, who is being crushed under the pressure of family life and work. One night, fed up with the fact he can't find the correct remote to turn on the TV, he goes to Bed, Bath, and Beyond to pick up a universal remote. In an incredibly cheap joke, he heads into the Beyond section and meets Morty (Christopher Walken) who gives him what he's looking for. Problem is, when Michael returns home he finds that the remote control lets him control his universe. He can pause, skip, rewind, and mute...Whatever he wants. Using the remote to skip arguments with his wife (the gorgeous Kate Beckinsale), hit his boss (David Hasselhoff, who manages to score some laughs), and get to work quicker we start to realize how similar this movie is to another recent comedy hit. "Bruce Almighty." This movie openly and unapologetically borrows from other, more superior films, that came before it much like the 2006 Robin Williams vehicle (no pun intended) "RV." Even though Michael uses the remote for selfish reasons, the movie is still funny until it runs out of steam is the second half. Not only does it run out of steam, it seems the screenwriters ran out of ideas. The first half of the movie is a typical Adam Sandler movie, lighthearted and mean-spirited. The second half is dark comedy, with some attempts at drama. The entire atmosphere and mood of the film change. A movie that had a new joke every few minutes now takes ten minutes to give us a joke and some of them aren't that funny. Christopher Walken didn't even get one laugh from me and he's an actor that usually walks into a movie (and he walks into a lot of them) and makes it funnier. There are some scenes in this movie that are hilarious though. My picks for the two funniest scenes in the movie are when Sandler hops a fence to chase some high school kids (doesn't sound very funny, but when you see the scene it will) and when Sandler is stuck in traffic and a man pulls up next to him singing and doing some dance moves. This scene (especially when Sandler turns the volume down) should rank as one of the funniest scenes of any Adam Sandler film. The humor is very mean-spirited and there are times when Michael is a pretty unlikable character, but the movie does have it's moments but it's not worthy of many (or, possibly, even one) repeat viewing. Although, I want to add that it's similarity to "Bruce Almighty" might involve the fact that this film was written by two of the three screenwriters of that film. Look for Jack Nicholson's daughter (2007 Miss Golden Globe) Lorraine Nicholson in a very brief scene as the 14-year-old version of Sandler's daughter.GRADE: C+

reviewText: What would you do if you could pause, rewind, fast-forward (basically all of the functions you can do with a DVD player) with your life? Would you rewind through prior events to relive the glory days? Or would you skip ahead to avoid waiting in traffic or enduring a fight, or would you pause or slow-down a moment to make it seemingly last forever. Wouldn't it be nice if we had such capabilities, just imagine what fun a person could have with that kind of power. In Sony Pictures hit comedy "Click" Adam Sandler gets to experience what would happen with that power first hand, and sometimes the outcome isn't exactly what he had in mind."Click" is the story of Michael Newman (Adam Sandler), a man without a lot of spare time on his hands. He has a hectic, very demanding job, a boss (David Hasselhoff) who is ungrateful for everything that he does, and a beautiful wife (Kate Beckinsale) and kids that deserve more attention than he is able to give. After feeling like life is going nowhere fast for himself, Michael visits a local store and meets a very odd man (Christopher Walken) who gives him what may be the greatest gift of all time, a universal remote. The difference between this universal remote and all others is that this one can not only control electronics, but everyday life as well. Soon, Michael is using the remote to skip arguments or boring conversations, speed up certain activities, even going back through his life to relieve the good times as a younger man. However, the remote begins to go haywire and Michael finds his life spinning out of his control, and the more he tries to fix things the worse they get. Now, he must try to regain what he's lost before it's too late."Click" is a movie that I wanted to see from the get-go. I thought it looked funny, it featured Adam Sandler, so I knew that was a safe bet, plus it had a great supporting cast, and what appeared to be a unique story that we all could relate to (meaning all of us that would like to have this type of control over certain aspects of life). When I finally got around to seeing the movie, I must say that it wasn't all that much like I expected. Sure, it was laugh out loud funny numerous times throughout the film, but there was seriousness to the story that was unexpected, yet a welcome addition at the same time. When the remote begins to mess with Michael's life, the movie shifts gears and becomes mostly a drama, revealing the consequences of rushing through life and how eventually it will just pass you by. It's not often that an Adam Sandler movie actually features a moral or message to the story, but this one did, and it didn't feel out of place at all.I was really surprised that for an Adam Sandler comedy, it was actually very different from his standard fare, there were his typical off-color jokes and remarks, but his character also had a sincerity to him that was uncommon for him to play. Watching him mature over the course of the film was interesting, because it forced Sandler to play more of his dramatic side rather than his slapstick side that he relies on the most. I haven't seen Adam Sandler's more serious movies "Reign Over Me" and "Punch Drunk Love", so I wasn't too sure how all of the serious elements were going to end up playing out when I saw that was definitely where the story was heading, but he handled it remarkably well. The rest of the cast was a mixture of sweet and caring (Michael's wife and kids), to somewhat strange (Michael's parents), to downright kooky and possibly on the verge of insanity (Christopher Walken's character). Each actor/actress was equally entertaining, and delivered very fun, interesting characters that were always enjoyable when on the screen. My favorite supportive character had to have been Chris Walken's, and I was happy that the writers gave him more than just a cameo of screen time. I believe he literally stole every scene he was in, and he did it so effortlessly, which is how it should be done.If you are a fan of Adam Sandler movies you should enjoy "Click", it does start out kind of slow, but after 10 minutes or so it really picks up, but there is some seriousness to it as well, so don't just expect to be laughing the entire time. But if you're not a fan of Sandler's films, and I know there are plenty of you out there, this is definitely one of his movies that I think you should see. It's a different type of Adam Sandler comedy, one with much more depth and originality than most of his efforts. Though not my favorite Adam Sandler movie, it definitely ranks up there around the top with "Big Daddy" and "The Longest Yard"."Click" is rated PG-13 for language and sensuality.
summary: What If You Could Control Everything...

reviewText: MOVIE: Adam Sandler has proven to be very successful at the box office. All of his films have been huge successes and I have enjoyed all of them despite some of them being rediculously stupid. In fact, the only Adam Sandler movie that I truly found unfunny was The Longest Yard, oh yeah, and Click. Adam Sandler's latest effort fails only on one level, but that one thing costs this movie everything that it has going for it. I mean, the premise is very interesting. We've all wished at one time or another that we could pause, rewind, or fast forward moments in life. So, Adam Sandler decides to make a comedy about it . . . or wait, maybe he wanted to make a drama. The film tries to be a comedy and a drama and that absolutely kills it. There is a difference between a comic drama (also known as a dramedy) and a movie that switches from comedy to drama instantly. It was awkward too because when the film becomes straight forward drama they still sneak in a joke now and then and no one in the theater laughs because no one wants to break the silence. The bottom line here is that the film has bad direction. It doesn't know if it wants to make you laugh or make you cry. They get the movie's message out though, which is simply to cherish life and family and not take it for granted. If you want to see movies that blend comedy and drama seamlessly then see The Weather Man or The Station Agent. Click is divided right in the middle, first half = comedy, second half = drama. The movie's funny moments are far and between though. I laughed a couple of times but nothing more than a chuckle now and then. The only thing about the film that I found remarkable was the makeup. Six time Academy Award winning makeup artist Rick Baker did the makeup for Click and it was amazing. Usually when you try to make actors look old it looks artificial and very stiff. Almost every actor and actress in the movie had to be shown as their older self at different stages of their lives, and the makeup work was so realistic and natural. Call me crazy, but I would not be shocked to see a nomination for Baker come Oscar time next year.ACTING: Adam Sandler is Adam Sandler and will always be Adam Sandler. He is the same in all of his roles and that right there is not a bad thing at all. We've come to love Sandler's brand of comedy so much that we would criticize him more if he were to change acting styles. He carries his character well and we believe his struggle and personal journey, but too bad the movie was poorly executed. Kate Beckinsale plays his wife, and while she has a presence onscreen she really has no chemistry with Sandler. I found her to be only eye candy for the movie since in almost every shot of her at home she is in a tight t-shirt and very short shorts. The film also has a bunch of great supporting roles mostly from Sandler's friends. You have Henry Winkler, Sean Astin, David Hasselhoff, and even Rob Schnieder has a cameo. We also can't forget Christopher Walken who is a perfect fit for Morty, the kooky scientist. A good cast that unfortunetly cannot save the movie's poor execution and direction.BOTTOM LINE: Bad direction leads to an overall awkward and unfunny experience. We start as a comedy and turn immediately into a drama. The tone shift is too drastic and it ruins the movie. The only notable things about the movie are Rick Baker's detailed makeup design and Rupert Gregson-Williams' light and supportive score. Pass this movie if you haven't seen it yet and just wait for DVD or HBO, because it really isn't anything special.
summary: The Movie Is Divided Into Part Comedy & Part Drama, & That Absolutely Kills It

reviewText: In "Click," Adam Sandler stars as Michael Newman, an overworked, underappreciated architect who's let his job replace his family. As Sandler's character ages, he begins to realize that he's not that great of a guy. reviewText: The closest Adam Sandler has come to a great film to this point in his career is "50 First Dates."  As far as I was concerned get rid of Rob Schneider as Ula and cut the vomiting Walrus and you would have a five star movie.  "Click" is in the same mold in that it combines Sandler's romantic side with a unusual situation and still insists on adding raunchy humor (I suppose there could be worse things than your dog trying to have sex with a giant stuffed duck, but let us not go there).  Consequently, "Click" is not an improvement on "50 First Dates," but I do not think that it constitutes a step backwards, which would be welcomed news.Sandler plays Michael Newman, who has married beyond his reach the gorgeous Donna (Kate Beckinsale), and has two young kids who love him, his son Ben (Joseph Castanon) and his daughter (Tatum McCann), despite the fact that he is so busy trying to make partner at the architecture firm where he works that he is ignoring his family more and more each day.  Every time he makes a promise to his family, he feels forced bo break it to satisfy John Ammer (David Hasselhoff) at work.  Things are getting so bad that Michael suddenly decides that what he needs ia a universal remote, just like the O'Doyle's next door, so that at least he can turn on his TV instead of the overhead fan.  So he heads off into the night and since Bed, Bath and Beyond is the only store opens, goes in to find his universal remote.  What he finds instead in the Beyond part of the store is Morty (Christopher Walken), who indeed has a universal remote, and not just your ordinary universal remote, as I assume everybody knows from the previews.I must say up front that I am pretty sure I could listen to Christopher Walken say anything, up to an including the instructions for using a universal remote or any other form of technology and be thoroughly entertained.  I would also add that Morty is absolutely right about Donna's body.  Anyway, with his amazing universal remote Michael quickly learns that he can use it to control his world and click away his problems, from muting his dog, fast-forwarding through fights with his wife, and pausing his boss so that he can slap the guy silly (although I think close-captioning would have been funnier for the scene with the Japanese businessmen at the restaurant).  Then Michael discovers the catch.It is not, as the trailer would lead you to believe, that the remote breaks.  But rather, as Morty explains, that it functions like Tivo in that it pays attention to what he is doing with the remote and automatically does it again.  So if you decide to fast-forward through an illness or foreplay with your wife, then that becomes the way it will be for the rest of your life.  This is a fairly interesting idea given the premise of the film, and the only real flaw in it is that once you establish Michael is on "auto pilot" during the chapters of his life that are skipped, then I do not see how he could be so successful at his business given that he has to use the remote to save the bacon with the Japanese firm.  But that is just because I pay attention to the rules of the game and like to take them to their logical extensions.Sandler has gathered familiar faces for this film, with Henry Winkler playing Michael's father, Sean Astin as Ben's swim coach, and even a nice cameo by Schneider, whose understate performance encouraged my hopes for this film.  Perhaps the biggest surprise here is that the raunchy humor got me to laugh out loud several times, even if a grown man striking back at the Eddie Haskell-wannabee who lives next door would be wrong, very wrong indeed (but still funny).  However, my wife would like me to state in no uncertain terms that what I was laughing at was clearly guy humor, and I am pretty sure she rolled her eyes and shook her head more often than she joined in on the laughing (it was hard to tell, the theater was dark and I was trying to watch the movie).Ultimately, the problem with the movie is the end, when Michael gets his second chance.  That is because the screenplay by Steve Koren and Mark O'Keefe (the team who did "Bruce Almighty") invests so much in the big epiphany and final grace note at the end of the third act that they apparently have nothing much to come up with for the epilogue where we are assured Michael and his family will live happily ever after.  "50 First Dates" had a great final payoff scene, and you can go all the way back to "It's a Wonderful Life" to see how well you can milk the return from Hell to the real world.  Granted, you will not top the end of the Hell sequence, but then you are not supposed to.  Still, there has to be a better payoff for what comes between that point and the start of the credits.  I am still rounding up on this one, but I should have been in a position to round down.  Final Note: Nice touch with getting Dolores O'Riordan from the Cranberries to show up to sing "Linger" live at the wedding.
summary: Controlling your universe is not all it is cracked up to be

reviewText: Click is a tricky film to review, it's not as great as some indicate it is, but not as bad as others indicate it is either.The fundamental problem with this film is it's juvenile humor, however, as a Happy Madison's production, that is almost mandatory, and based on that expectation, it is not excessive, when compared to some of Sandler's other films such as "Happy Gilmnore" or even "Waterboy". When the film sticks to the core plot and leaves out much of the silly low brow humor (with a few exceptions, such as the scene with his wife's crazy friend, or the scene with the Japanese businessmen), it really excels, as the characters are actually interesting and other than the silly humor, the relationships feel real.  When the film hits emotionally, it hits hard, and yet at the same time, if you were to take this humor out, it would be a rather mundane, rote, and over sentimental film with just another take on "A Christmas Carol" or "It's a Wonderful Life".There are a lot of themes in this film that I have yet to see touched upon in the reviews here. Yes, it plays in the whole 'Spend time with family bit,' but on a deeper level then I normally see in films especially in a comedy. It deeply comments on how people have a tendency to follow the example they see, and  not what they hear.  This is aptly exhibited through his daughters use of vulgarities and his son's poor eating habits; both things they watched their father do. We also see this exhibited through some changes in his son later on when those bad eating habits are changed to good habits through the influence of his health nut stepfather (Sean Astin).A constant recurring theme in this film is struggle of money vs time, which we can see started when he was a child in a flashback camping scene, with a rivalry from childhood (we only see this rival in a flashback, in the present we only see his son and wife).  His rival's son is constantly gloating about all the "cool" stuff he has, and Sandler's character is very immature, like he has never grown out of that rivalry (cause he has not), and even results to picking on his rival's son, which at times is funny, such as the time his son and the kid our playing catch and he pauses it and moves his glove so the ball hits him in the face, other times it just comes across as petty.It is truly sad that this man never truly grew up, and what the experience with the remote gives him, is a chance to finally mature in to an adult mentally and emotionally.  I would like to say there are not people like this in real life, but I have met them, still stuck in the past, still striving for things in the wrong way, and scared and hurting people in their path out of habit.  The only good thing he took with him as hew grew up was his dream of being financially free (which is a great dream to have), but again, he takes the wrong road to achieve it, by constantly trying to bend over backwards and please his boss at the peril of his personal life and family's happiness.It also comments on the pitfalls of a job (something which the American school system programs us to have, rather than say, owning a business and creating a passive cash flow) and how we become controlled by them.  His wife at one point even calls him a 'wage slave', which I found to be a very apt description of someone climbing up the corporate ladder.  He is constantly chasing a dream that can't happen with a job, it is not possible to have both time and money in a corporate world.Although he is seeking to gain time by losing it in the short term, which is actually smart (As he states to his wife, when he is making millions he will hire a bunch of ppl to do everything for him), but he is using the wrong means to do so (he needs a passive cash flow, not an active one such as job for that) and is neglecting his key relationships in the process, which is the real folly he commits here.He constantly equates corporate success with freedom, and is constantly comparing himself to a childhood rival who 'Has it all.' Instead of just realizing he has it good with his Wife and kids, and actually has a really nice house and life if he'd just see what's in front of him (not that its bad to strive for more, but that plan should be a team effort of the family, not a solo effort, if you are married), but he cannot see it, due to his constant focus on other women, other ppl's money, and why he doesn't like his life, something that most people do, and it is this focus on others and blaming others for our problems  that keeps us as humans from ever truly being satisfied.The film doesn't say money is bad or that success is bad, but rather, when that journey neglects your family, it's not a path worth taking.  The film  aptly shows how marriages suffer when you lose your focus on why you're doing something and the how becomes the why instead of the why being the why.Some see the ending as a co-pout, and yes, it is, but by the end of the film, I saw it as a great relief, as I was nearly hysterically crying the first time I saw it and it allowed me to appreciate what came before without being morbidly depressed, but on repeated viewings, not watching the ending after the sad denouement, might make the film better.  I am torn, as to if it it hadn't ended that way, would it  have put the focus on his failures instead of how he could change his life around, but if it ended with him lying face up (I suppose it'd be a lot like the ending to the 'Bridge to Terrabithia'),  might it have changed the overall message of the film?  Given the often light-hearted tone, the ending was congruent with keeping this tone, and  the ending was not actually out of character for a film of this nature(13 Going on 30 had a similar ending, but it definitely worked better in the overall scheme of the film), one in which the point was to make you laugh, but hopefully think a little as well.Although surprisingly contemplative and thought provoking  at times, it is the ever persistent silly tone that both makes this stand out in the cannon of films of this nature, but also might keep it from being truly great, and why it will most likely never become a classic, although it is worth watching if you can can enjoy the silly jokes.God Bless ~Amy

reviewText: You either really like Adam Sandler or you loathe him.  He's a polarizing guy.  I really liked him -- until this movie.  It isn't bad enough to walk out of, and there are moments of fun, but a large percentage of it is painful.  Let's start at the beginning.The concept is straight out of Junior League Screenwriting 101 -- 75% borrowed, 25% original.  Actually, make that 85% borrowed.  Like that Twilight Zone episode about the lout who obtains a stop watch that can stop time, Adam Sandler plays a lout who finds a "universal remote" that can not only pause the world (like the stop watch), but can mute it, rewind it, and fast-forward through all manner of unpleasantness -- and, it turns out, pleasantness as well.  But, it becomes apparent about twenty minutes into the story that the writers are way over their heads.  Not only do the seem to have no imagination as to what a character might really do with a device like this, they start adding "rules" to try to twist some kind of a character arc out of this device (like this clunky concept -- at least in the hands of these writers -- that the remote "automatically programs itself based upon what you do with it" that, sadly, becomes the central artifice for the entire movie).Sandler, in addition, has never been less sympathetic.  Not only hasn't he aged well, he's also not really that funny anymore.  The schtick that peppers all of his films really feels like schtick in this movie.  Bad schtick.  I suppose it was inevitable that it would get old.The supporting cast is completely wasted, both with bad lines and stupid set pieces. Christopher Walken, whose facial expressions alone can be comedic genius, visibly struggles with wooden dialogue, and is forced to inhabit an old joke:  the "Beyond" department of Bed, Bath & Beyond.  (It's one thing when Peter Griffin told this joke a couple of years back on Family Guy, but seeing it resurrected as a centerpiece of this movie is, well, pathetic.  Either the writers were cynics and felt that middle America might still laugh at it, or they thought they were being funny and original. I'm not sure which is worse.)Kate Beckensale is beautiful, but it is impossible to accept her as Sandler's wife.  She's too nice, to sweet, and too attractive.  Now if Click was just a slapstick comedy, we might be able to deal with this.  But that leads to the movie's biggest problem:  It turns into this maudlin and insulting mess, a preachy message movie about "family comes first."  At that point, it stops being funny entirely.  It tries pulling at heart strings with these big, clumsy hands.  Frankly, it's just about insufferable.And then, the biggest idiocy of all ... [spoiler alert] ...We find out it was all a DREAM ... but, cliche of cliches ... it really wasn't a DREAM.Don't waste your quarters on this junk.

reviewText: "Click" is a predictable yet sentimental little movie about Michael Newman (Adam Sandler), an architect who has a difficult time juggling his career with his home life. One night Michael end up at a Bed Bath & Beyond looking to purchase a universal remote control. Venturing into the mysterious "Beyond" room, Michael meets a mysterious man (Christopher Walken) who gives him a remote control that's supposed to be the top of the line in technological advancement. Michael soon discovers that he has the ability to control every aspect of his life. He can fast-forward through arguments with his wife (Kate Beckinsale), avoid boring dinners with his parents (Henry Winkler and Julie Kavner), and even mute the family dog.Unfortunately, Michael learns that having so much control over his own life isn't all fun and games. The universal remote eventually begins to run on auto pilot, and Michael begins fast-forwarding through large chunks of his life. He zips ahead a year in anticipation of a promotion, but learns that his home life has suffered irreparable damage. Michael eventually loses his wife to his son's swimming instructor (Sean Astin) and has no real relationship with his children. Before he knows what's happening, Michael is suddenly an old man and has witnessed his entire life go by in the blink of an eye. Fast-forwarding through life has resulted in Michael missing out on his life entirely, and he is more miserable than he ever thought possible.There is a lot of gross humor in this movie which did not appeal to me at all. I think the film would have been a lot more moving if the director chose to leave out all the farting/flapping/humping jokes. In spite of all that, though, "Click" treats the audience to a modern version of "It's a Wonderful Life" and demonstrates that the best part of life is actually living it: not even the difficult parts are worth missing.

reviewText: Michael Newman (Adam Sandler) has a typical corporate middle management conflict: Work vs. Family. Forcing his wife to repriorotize a promised family outing at the "do it or lose your standing" threat of his boss, Newman goes out on the only errand for which he can think to leave the house: to look for an Universal Remote to simplify the "which one do I use for this?" issue he's been fumbling.The only store open is Bed, Bath and Beyond. Newman flops on a mattress to rest, from which he sees the Magical Blue Door below the sign, "BEYOND." A strange man in a blue coat named Morty (Christopher Walken) takes him to a new Universal Remote model sitting atop empty shelves. This special model works on more than the TV; it works on the "screen" of life, as well. Morty gives Newman his phone number to call, and gives the remote for free.Newman begins realizing the remote's powers when his wife is intensely talking to him about serious family issues, and he says, "Freeze," as he pauses the TV - and realizes that he has paused her, as well. He realizes he can avoid unpleasantries, and, as he is focused on getting ahead at work, he learns that he can fast-forward though such boring events as family dinners in order to get to his work. He sees fast-forwarding as a way to fulfill his other commitments without having to actually live through them.Newman uses Morty's phone number when he doesn't remember committing to something of which his wife reminds him. Morty shows Newman that, during fast-forwards, Newman is on something called Autopilot, meaning that he is physically present and able to respond at levels not involving his conscious participation. Morty shows Newman "the Menu," from which Newman may navigate through his life. After perusing some scenes, Morty advises Newman that the remote has a special built-in feature that assesses his usage habits and begins performing his preferences, automatically.Newman already fast-forwarded activities in the marital bed once, and it appears that he is stuck with these activities in fast-forward mode for all of "Beyond." He didn't get the promotion he wanted when he wanted it, so he fast-forwarded to when he did get the promotion, thinking it would only be a few months. It was over a year later, and he found that his children already didn't like to do some of the things they liked "only a few moments ago."Morty tells Newman that Newman's preference has clearly been set to fast-forward between Work issues, and the remote has accommodated that preference. Newman pops into awareness to find himself promoted, obese, divorced, hospitalized, at his son's wedding, and hospitalized again. He learns that his father (Henry Winkler) has died, and when Newman faces Morty again, Morty takes him to the last time he saw his father. Newman was on autopilot. Now, Newman can see how destructive autopilot has been in his life.This was where I jumped my rating to four stars. Newman was a remote visitor to his own life, living on autopilot, not getting involved, not loving the people in front of him. He jumped from pinnacle to pinnacle, not involved in the process, not sharing himself...not understanding that life, at its finest, is living moment to moment, being completely aware of what is before him, loving who is in front of him, speaking his truth, not chasing, on the outside, after something that he already had on the inside. After divorcing Newman, his wife married someone who was present, and Newman's children thrived in that relationship.(Spoiler Alert now 'til the end)Newman got something the rest of us don't get in this one lifetime; a second chance to take back time and do it again. He awakens on the mattress to what may have been a dream (no blue "Beyond" door this time). He immediately goes home to reinstate the family outing. The remote shows up on his countertop with a note from Morty ("You'll know what to do this time").Newman puts the remote and note into the drawer and walks out to be a participant in his own life.
summary: Life on Autopilot: A Remote Perspective

reviewText: A CHRISTMAS CAROL....ITS A WONDERFUL LIFE...CLICK.  Yes, all three have one thing in common:  they all show their heroes what their lives could have been like had they made different choices.  CLICK certainly isn't the kind of classic the other two films have become, but for entertaining its audience, CLICK manages to click.Adam Sandler obviously trying to hone his dramatic skills stars as Michael Newman, a workaholic whose drive for achievement is alienating him from his family.  Kate Beckinsale is his lovely wife whose patience and endurance are wearing thin.  Sean Astin is the speedoclad jock who has taken Sandler's son under his wing; David Hasselhoff is his egocentric and self-centered boss; Henry Winkler and Julie Kavner are his warmhearted youthful acting parents.  And Christopher Walken is the mysterious Morty who supplies Sandler with a remote control that can control his life.  He can fast forward past arguments, turn off the volume of his dog's barking, etc.The movie's first half is the expected slapstick, lowbrow humor with lots of sexual and flatulent references, and it's pretty funny; the movie segues however into a dramatic look at how things change when Sandler keeps fast forwarding past important events just so he can reach his goal to be Hasselhoff's partner.  Wonderful makeup effects by Rick Baker heighten the reality of this section of the movie, and it almost has a real bummer of an ending...almost.I enjoyed CLICK and was impressed with the overall performances.  Sandler is to be commended for taking artistic chances, and CLICK enables him to do so.

reviewText: They keep letting this guy (Adam Sandler) make movies; most likely because audiences flock to see most of his stuff, as was the case with "Click" (2006). "Click" is Sandler's take on "It's a Wonderful Life" (1946). At least I assume the Jimmy Stewart classic was what they were aiming at because the end result seems more of a blend of "Scrooged" and "Being There". "Click" is probably Sandler's all-time best performance; in the style of and equal in quality to a good Tim Allen performance. He is assisted by a supporting cast of recognizable actors; Henry Winkler, Julie Kavner, Christopher Walken, David Hasselhoff, and Sean Astin. There is also a brief appearance by Jack Nicholson's daughter Lorraine, who looks amazingly like Jack back in his "Easy Rider" days; this is actually kind of scary.Kate Beckinsale has the same role that Winona Ryder had in Mr. Deeds. While neither of them rank up there with Jean Arthur (the heroine in both Capra classics) they are still two of the best actresses out there today. I'm assuming both were very well paid because the scripts offer little opportunity for either to showcase their considerable acting skills. In fact the mismatch between talent and opportunity produces a strange discordance in both films. This might be one of those cases where a less talented performer would have been a better fit.George Bailey (and Scrooge) had an attitude adjustment after being granted visions of the past and the future by his guardian angel. Michael Newman's (Sandler) angel (Walken), who works in the local Bed, Bath and Beyond store, gives him a television remote control that he can click whenever he wants to fast-forward his life past the parts that are annoying distractions to his workaholic aspirations. At first this seems like a wonderful device as he can dispense with the family interactions that complicate his life. But Michael soon discovers that the device programs itself and shifts him further and further into the future. The remote can also freeze a scene, mute the sound, and select past scenes from his life; but the film mostly concentrates on its fast-forwarding function."Click" is technically a comedy and apparently some find a lot to laugh about. There are some funny moments early in the production but I found the humor to be in short supply for most of the story.Ultimately "Click" has a "Groundhog Day" sort of theme. That in tuning out much of what life has to offer we miss life itself. Since this cold detached way of living is what most of us do (at least to some degree) it tends to undermine any comic quality the film might have. Of course unless your taste in comedy runs to Sandler's usual focus on bodily functions it doesn't take much to do this anyway.Inexplicably, even at his most detached, patient and accepting people surround Michael. His wife (Beckinsale), his parents (Winkler and Kavner), and his children continue to love him despite the absence of any lovable qualities. Similar to those who love this film.Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.

reviewText: Click isn't a bad movie.  It's just not a very funny or original one.  With a plot that could have been culled from an array of anthology shows, or even a sketch comedy show (I did see it done on one), Sandler and co. tread on dangerous, often predictable ground. Supposedly, comedy should ensue.Here is where problems come in.  Watching Sandler glide through the future after his remote continually fast forwards, we are given dreary future events.  Occaisonally, there are spotty laughs, usually regarding sex or bodily function.  Either way, they are crude and inappropriate for the tone of the rest of the film.Then there are similarities between It's a Wonderful Life/Scrooge, and any number of stories that ask "what if" and in the end, present themselves as cautionary tales.  This film is very predictable from start to finish.There are moments to this film - and the big moment is Sandler.  Sandler has been positioned as a sort of everyman who somehow succeeds in all his films.  He has a likeability that allows him to succeed in spite of the material.  However, scripts often have lewd humor that keep Sandler from reaching his potential, as he did in Spanglish, Puch Drunk Love, and even in earlier comedies like the Wedding Singer.  Take the unneccessary humor away and you have a much more watchable, if predictable, movie to watch.

reviewText: This story was fabricated quite well. You got your average Joe (Adam Sandler) working for a firm where he's busts his butt to get some recognition, plus some sort of promotion.  He's so focused on his job that he tends to neglect his family, canceling vacation plans and fails to show up for school events, etc. however, in the long run, he's working hard so that his family can have more.In reality, many people don't realize that they are inadvertently dissing their family while thinking that they are trying to be successful in their job. Many people don't see it, but that's why some spouses leave their husbands because they are never home for them or the children.  They don't know how to appreciate what they have because they always want more. Or, their superiors tell them that they will earn a promotion for continually conquering challenges thrown at them, while all the while, the superior enjoys all the benefits that the employee worked hard for. Most all employers are the evil puppeteers of this true reality that seems to break up homes.In this film, Morty is subsequently, the devil in the flesh.  He gives Michael Newman a remote control.  But, not one that controls his TV. It is one that controls his life. By using the remote control, he make all his own choices. What he wants to do, what he wants to skip. He just jumps ahead (with the skip chapter button on the remote) so he can get past the unpleasant things he wishes to avoid.  What he thinks should be just a few days, actually ends up being years into the future. Years of losing all the wonderful things he could have done with his family, if he didn't go and put his job first.The spin on this film that makes it so devastatingly real, is that, if we could skip all the unpleasantness of our lives we would just find ourselves deeper into the future, and no closer to gaining all that we strive for. In fact, we would only see what we've lost, when trying so hard to have more.So people have said, that "this is not a comedy". Well, comedy was there only to make it so it wouldn't be so depressing.  If all the comedy was taken out, this would feel like an extremely horrific episode of the "Twilight Zone" with all the outcomes of reality in tact. I think this would be a great movie to play during the Christmas season because people need to remember that: "Family comes first!" Forgetting that, is why some families fall apart.

reviewText: Adam Sandler became famous playing comical, crude, and manic characters.  But, like many comedians, Sandler has illustrated that he isn't just a funny man and is able to handle more serious, dramatic material, too.  Showing that his dramatic turn in PUNCH DRUNK LOVE wasn't just a one-time fluke, Sandler stars in CLICK, a transition piece for the actor that allowed him to display his dramatic acting chops but not completely forsaking his comic roots.  CLICK can best be described as a cross between IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE and the classic medieval tale of Faustus.Sandler portrays a young architect named Michael Newman.  Michael works for an incredibly pompous man named Ammer (David Hasselhoff).  Michael is a man who doesn't know how to say no to Ammer's requests and finds himself spending more and more time at work.  Professionally, it has started to provide benefits, but at the cost of alienating himself from his family.Deeply frustrated one evening with all the lack of control the different remote controls in his house seem to have (as well as the lack of control he seems to have with his life), Michael sets out to a Bed, Bath, and Beyond (can you say product placement) to find a universal remote.  Michael finds himself wandering into the darkest corners of the "Beyond" part of the store where he meet Morty (Christopher Walken).  Morty gives Michael a truly universal remote. It solves his remote control problem.  However, as Michael soon learns, the universal remote also works with his real life.  He is able to mute his wife during arguments, fast forward through boring family dinners, or pause a moment in time to perform a practical joke.  Michael thinks the remote is the greatest thing in the world until he learns that the remote begins operating upon memory and then Michael's life truly runs out of control.CLICK is a decent movie.  It has some funny moments, but it's also a dramatic film with a positive message about appreciating the simple, yet finer things in life.  The acting by the entire cast is well done and though there are a few cruder moments of humor (typical of a Sandler picture) there isn't anything outrageous.  I will say that about three-fourths of the way into the movie things became somewhat confusing for me, but after thinking and talking about the movie later things became clear.Overall, CLICK is a must-see for Sandler diehards and just a regular entertaining movie for everyone else.

In today's modern culture, it is thought provoking about work and life balance.  Highly recommend it.

reviewText: I see that online here this movie has had mixed reviews. I tend to think that this movie was decent. Although the outcome was very predictable, no suspense or disguise at all, the material in between was entertaining.  Adam sandler plays Michael, a father who has had work become a priority over his family.  The weekend of the fourth of july, Michael gets assigned a huge work project, and decided to cancel his families planned fourth of july camping trip to work.  During the course of that evening, he gets frustrated with all of his remotes trying to watch a video for work, and set of to find a Universal remote. Being late, the only store that happened to be open was Bed,Bath, and Beyond.  Well, little did he know he would be involve in discovering just what "beyond" stands for.  Christopher Walken plays the store attendant that helps him get his remote, which turns out to be a remote to control his universe.  From their, the movie takes off as we see him trying to control his universe.  Beware though, the remote will "auto progrom" , and he gets his life turined upside down once the remote learns his habits.Yes the ending was predictable, and I am left to wonder why he just didn't reprogram the remote, IE change his habits or pust some of the other buttons, but the movie is what it is. At least rent this one, but I say it is a good one for the collection.
summary: Yes, a little predictable, but a decent movie for Sandler

reviewText: When one thinks of an Adam Sandler film, the phrase "juvenile humor" immediately comes to mind, filled with low-brow humor and outlandish acting.  Fortunately, "Click" is a departure (for the most part) from that categorization by providing an interesting story, developed characters, and very solid acting.For a basic plot summary, "Click" sees Michael Newman (Sandler) struggling to find time for his family while wearing himself out for his never-impressed boss.  On a routine trip to find a universal TV remote, Michael runs into a crazy scientist (played by Christopher Walken) who gives him a "universal remote", alright...one that can control his entire life!  Hilarity, emotions, & hijinks ensue.Besides the novel concept, this movie outshines other Sandler flicks due to its heart.  While shaping up (in the early goings) to be a hijinks comedy, somewhere along the way a heavy dose of emotion is thrown into the proceedings.  By the end of the film, the viewer will actually care about the main characters and want to see their resolutions.Granted, "Click" does still contain some of the typical Sandler low-brow humor, but it isn't too over-the-top or suffocating.  Far outweighing that aspect is the above-average acting from pretty much the entire cast, which produces a real connection between characters and audience.Overall, "Click" is a fun little movie (though not for the younger kiddies) that may (at least in a small way) change your perception of Mr. Sandler.  This isn't his goofy "Waterboy" or farcical "Billy Madison".  Instead, director Frank Coraci crafts an actual storyline filled with character development and fun concepts.
